column1: Wishing everyone and their families faith hope and love this #ThanksgivingDay and always.  May we remember those who've lost a loved one during this difficult time and show gratitude to those who've been on the frontlines keeping us going.   Many blessings. Muchas bendiciones. https://t.co/zpZ1laI5ah

This #Thanksgiving please follow @CDCgov guidelines.  We should be staying put at home & avoiding travel if at all possible. We should also continue to #SocialDistance #WashOurHands & #WearAMask.  This is how we'll help keep others healthy this holiday season. #DoYourPart https://t.co/wCpMtU5iBO
Dot gov! About time. https://t.co/ACdBWxxF0y
@RepLucyMcBath Thinking of you amiga! Big hug and know I’m there with you every step of the way!

Learn from the Aragonez family & stay home this Thanksgiving!  A couple of weeks ago they had a small family gathering where they all got infected including 3 family members who didn’t attend.  If we all stay home this Thanksgiving we will all be able to celebrate next year. https://t.co/CHt4gtFNkx

.@AliMayorkasʼs history-making nomination to lead the Department of Homeland Security which oversees our immigration system sends a powerful signal. If confirmed by the Senate DHS will be led by a Latino a Cuban-American and an immigrant. https://t.co/ncZBz7IFCh

America is ready to lead the world not retreat from it. President-elect Biden has put forward a team of experienced crisis-tested foreign policy national security and law enforcement leaders with diverse backgrounds and fresh perspectives who will be ready to lead on Day One. https://t.co/yvzO8NchDc

3/ While in Congress I filed a bipartisan bill (HR 7832) to rename the Broadway Street post office in Houston after Mr. Benny Martinez for his important role coordinating this historic meeting and his lifetime advocacy for Latinos in Houston.
2/ President Kennedy accepted the invitation over one thousand others and the event went down in history as the first time a sitting President sat with a Latino civil rights organization.

1/ On a day like yesterday November 21 1963 President John F. Kennedy met with Mexican American rights activists from LULAC and Viva Kennedy Clubs in Houston. John Herrera with help from Benny Martinez invited President Kennedy to the LULAC State Director's Ball. https://t.co/yksG2iBFi5
Happy birthday to @abc13houston on 66 years of high-quality fact-based reporting. Thank you for everything you do for the Houston region. ¡Muchas felicidades!

Here's your weekly update! This week I was back in D.C. where I voted on many bills #ForThePeople. These bills included support for our veterans protections against #COVID19 related scams and efforts to strengthen apprenticeship programs in America. https://t.co/pMOjNFzEaP

Today we say the names of transgender and gender non-conforming people who have been killed this year.  They were killed for being who they are. I want every transgender and gender non-conforming person to know I will always have your back.  #TransDayOfRemembrance https://t.co/D92SLULTux

Today I voted in support of the National Apprenticeship Act of 2020 – a proposal to create 1 MILLION new apprenticeship opportunities to help Americans get back to work.  As we recover from #COVID19 it’s critical to build back our workforce with good paying jobs. https://t.co/gS8quALkWS
I want to wish President-elect Joe Biden a very happy birthday.  Quiero desearle un feliz cumpleaños al presidente electo Joe Biden. https://t.co/QjMtDq7h0C

Diabetes is especially prevalent in the Latino community.   While the Latino community is large and diverse with people from Cuba Puerto Rico Mexico Central and South America all groups are at much higher risk of developing Type 2 diabetes.  #DiabetesAwarenessMonth https://t.co/NznRtvDVVU

Millions of Americans are impacted by diabetes every year and millions of Americans struggle to afford their insulin on a daily basis. That is why November is dedicated to raising awareness about diabetes.  Learn more at: @CDCDiabetes or @MinorityHealth  #DiabetesAwarenessMonth https://t.co/MEPqU12Bjk

History made.  #MadamVicePresidentElect https://t.co/vjs76oycHI
Read my full statement below⬇️ https://t.co/xoc9ldqw27

4/ Today little girls and boys all across the country and in fact the world get to see the promise of America through her. As a woman I could not be more proud of Madam Vice President-elect Kamala Harris.

3/ Lastly I must say something about the glass-ceiling shattering moment we are witnessing today. Kamala Harris just became the first woman the first black person and the first Southeast Asian person ever elected as Vice-President of the United States.

2/ Together they will heal a divided country as we work to control the spread of COVID-19 and help families affected by this virus build back better. The work ahead of us won’t be easy but I know Joe and Kamala are ready to get to work.

1/ The American people have spoken and we can all breathe a sigh of relief. President-elect Joe Biden and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris are going to lead this country with heart and compassion. They will work every day for those who voted for them and those who didn’t.

3/ Unfortunately injustice against Mexican Americans and people of color continues.   As a country we still have a lot of work to do to combat racism and injustice against people of color.

2/ His brutal execution without due process led to an international examination of long-standing racism against Mexican Americans.   Protests about Rodríguez’ death broke out in the U.S. and Mexico even invoking an investigation from the government of Mexico.

1/ In November 1910 20-year old Antonio Rodríguez became a victim of lynching in Texas.  Rodríguez was charged with murder of a local townswoman. Before his day in court mobs broke into his jail cell kidnapped Rodríguez and burned and lynched his body. https://t.co/QYNq5Zczb7
